Introduction

The purpose of this Executive Summary is to provide the public with information about the Ross Incineration Services, Inc., ("RIS") Risk Management Plan ("RMP"). RIS is a commercial hazardous waste treatment and storage facility that processes substances covered by the accidental release prevention regulations under section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act. All facilities covered by these regulations must develop and implement programs that prevent accidental releases of regulated substances and reduce the severity of releases that may occur. These risk management programs must be described in an RMP. The RMP must include a hazard assessment, a prevention program and an emergency response program. RIS' RMP was originally submitted to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency by June 21, 1999. The regulations require sources to update and resubmit RMPs at least every five years or sooner if any changes occur. RIS has developed its risk management programs and routinely updated its RMP to comply with regulation.



It is RIS' policy to provide its associates with a safe work environment and its neighbors with a safe environment in which to live. RIS is also committed to providing its associates with safe equipment and is committed to complying with State and Federal regulations regarding working conditions and accident prevention. The personal health and safety of RIS associates and neighbors is of primary importance. To this end, RIS maintains safety and health programs that employ an aggressive approach toward injury and illness prevention focusing on a safe work environment. RIS operates within guidelines set by its Statement of Environmental, Health and Safety Policy, which follows. 

?    Our business success and our commitment to protection of human health and the environment are consistent and complimentary goals. 

?    We demonstrate leadership in protection of human health and the environment in our workplace, marketplace and the community. 

?    We comply w

ith all applicable safety, health and environmental regulations, and hold the broader goals of: eliminating preventable injuries; preventing adverse environmental and health impacts; reducing wastes and emissions; and promoting resource conservation. 

?    Management and all associates are collectively and individually responsible for compliance with safety, health and environmental regulations, policies and procedures. 

?    We communicate our safety, health and environmental achievements and challenges openly, honestly, clearly, and professionally with associates, customers, our community, and government agencies. 

?    This policy will guide all our decisions and actions that have potential safety, health or environmental impacts. 



Safety Information 

RIS is regulated under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act ("RCRA"), the Clean Air Act ("CAA") Maximum Achievable Control Technology ("MACT") regulation, and the Occupational Safety Health Administration ("OSHA"). These regulations require RIS to operate under strict specifications, which protect RIS' people, the environment, and the community. Under the RCRA regulations, RIS has applied for and been granted a RCRA Part B permit. The purpose of the RCRA regulations (and the Part B permit) is to assure that RIS operates its processes in a manner that protects human health and environment. The RIS facility operation was designed to prevent accidental releases as well as mitigate potential releases. Daily inspections are conducted for the operational processes, storage areas and secondary containment areas. Additional inspection and monitoring (also required by RCRA and the Part B permit) are conducted to assure that the processes are operating within permitted and regulated specifications. 



Under the CAA MACT regulations, RIS has applied for and been granted a Title V permit. The purpose of the CAA regulations (and the Title V permit) is to assure that RIS operates its processes in a manner that protects human

health and environment. The RIS facility operation conducts required Comprehensive Performance Tests of its operating systems to ensure that the system operates as designed. Additional inspections and monitoring of the operational processes are required by RIS' Title V permit and assure that RIS' processes are operating within Title V permitted and regulated specifications. 



The OSHA Process Safety Management ("PSM") regulation parallels the RMP program. Both were created to minimize unexpected releases of toxic, reactive, or flammable liquids and gases. To ensure safe and healthful workplaces, OSHA issued the Process Safety Management ("PSM") standard (29 CFR 1910.119), which outlines facility requirements associated with processing certain chemicals. RIS has a comprehensive PSM management program that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices to minimize the potential for an unexpected chemical release. 



RIS firmly believes that a release of a hazardous chemical from its facility that would adversely impact the environment or cause concern to human health is very unlikely. Waste management processes at RIS are engineered and constructed with controls to prevent or mitigate off-site releases of hazardous chemicals to the environment. Current operating and safety procedures further reduce the possibility of such a release. RIS' Emergency Response Program minimizes hazards to human health and the environment from fires and unplanned releases of hazardous waste constituents from facility operations. This program includes provisions to coordinate on-site emergency response personnel if a chemical spill or fire were to occur. It also includes provisions to coordinate response to site emergencies, if necessary, with local, State and Federal emergency management personnel. Emergency Coordinators ("EC") and Emergency Response Team ("ERT") personnel employed by RIS are trained to control chemical spills and fires to minimize the possibility of an

off-site release of hazardous chemicals.



RIS associates receive extensive training to enable them to perform their jobs correctly and safely. Each RIS operations associate receives hundreds of hours of supervised, on the job training to learn operating procedures and proper techniques to operate process equipment and machinery. All RIS associates receive more than 24 hours of OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 training within their first six months of employment. This safety training helps RIS associates recognize and manage the hazards associated with their jobs. It also provides organized and consistent procedures to respond to emergency situations, including chemical spills and fires. Refresher training is provided annually to apprise each associate of facility process upgrades, potential process hazards, and safety procedure changes. RIS trainers review emergency response responsibilities, contingency plan implementation criteria and site evacuation procedures during this annual training. Additionally, each RIS associate receives monthly or quarterly safety training where he or she focuses on applicable OSHA safety procedures and established safety programs. Qualified safety and health professionals provide training at RIS. 



RIS personnel meet annually with the local emergency service providers. Discussions at this meeting include the location and layout of the facility, properties of hazardous wastes and the associated hazards, places where facility personnel will normally be working, entrances to and roads inside the facility, evacuation routes, the potential associated hazards of emergency response and any changes that have been made to the emergency response plan. In addition, the responsibilities of each party are reviewed. Updated emergency response plans are shared with outside responders at the annual meeting.



Since 1999, RIS has voluntarily participated in the OSHA On-Site Consultation Program through the Ohio Department of Commerce, Division of Labor and Wo

rker Safety. This program provides an independent evaluation of the RIS health and safety programs including PSM by an OSHA consultant. Evaluations are made on all aspects of these programs through inspections and associate interviews. RIS continues to participate in the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's On-Site Consultation Program. Having this independent input has enabled RIS to strengthen its outstanding programs and to better incorporate associate involvement in its efforts. Moreover, RIS' compliance with the OSHA PSM regulation requires a periodic series of health and safety program Compliance Audits by experienced RIS personnel. 



Facility Information 

RIS is a commercial hazardous waste treatment and storage facility located in rural Lorain County, Ohio. RIS began its waste management operations in 1949. Its primary method of waste treatment is and has always been incineration. The entire RIS facility encompasses approximately 80 acres and is surrounded by farmland, dense woodland and a small residential area. RIS thermally treats non-hazardous and hazardous solid and liquid wastes including spent solvents, paint solids, off specification chemicals, and chemical products from manufacturing facilities. RIS has drum and bulk storage capabilities and is permitted to store waste for treatment in tanks, in a covered, open sided container storage facility, in a container storage facility, on two bulk storage area pads, in waste storage bays and in an oxidizer storage building. RIS complies with State and Federal regulations for hazardous waste treatment and storage facilities (RCRA). RIS operates under State and Federal RCRA Part B permits. It also complies with OSHA standards and State and Federal air standards specific to the treatment of hazardous wastes. RIS operates under a State issued Title V Permit. 



Waste Management Processes 

For the purposes of this submittal, RIS considered four processes that encompass the entirety of its facility

operations. Each of these processes is made up of several units. These processes include: 

1)    Container storage - storage in containers can occur in the Container Storage Facility ("CSF"), which is a covered, open sided facility, in the Container Storage Area ("CSA"), on two bulk storage area concrete pads, in waste storage bays and in an oxidizer storage building. 

2)    Movement and handling of bulk waste (tankers and roll-off containers) and small containers onsite (including waste repackaging activities performed outdoors and staging and set-up for processing near the incineration system.) 

3)    Waste feeds to the Incineration System (Feed mechanisms). Although RIS' feed mechanisms individually would not exceed a Threshold Quantity ("TQ"), there is a potential to exceed a TQ collectively.

4)      Dock, Tank Farm, Metering- pumping of liquid waste into tank farm or tankers for waste feed processing from drums, totes, or tankers. 



To determine the applicability of this Accidental Release Prevention regulation to the RIS facility, RIS initially reviewed its records for a three-year period to determine which regulated chemicals were received and managed at RIS above the TQ. RIS continues a review process to determine potential applicability. The following list of the chemicals are being registered. It is important to note that these chemicals are received from manufacturers as wastes and waste mixtures rather than as products. 



Toxic Substances: 

?    Isopropyl Chloroformate 

?    Toluene Diisocyanate (Mixed Monomers)

?    Formaldehyde

?    Toluene-2,4-diisocyanate 



Hazard Assessment 

The regulated chemicals received above the TQ are evaluated in an off-site consequence analysis that considers management of these chemicals in the processes described above. Both a Worst-Case analysis and Alternative-Case analyses were run following standard assumptions found in U.S. EPA's Off-Site Consequence Analysis Guidance and modeling program.



The possibility of the Worst-C

ase or Alternative-Case scenarios actually occurring is very remote. Although RIS does not typically receive regulated toxic chemicals in pure form, RIS may exceed a TQ with isopropyl chloroformate, formaldehyde, toluene 2,4-dissocyanate and toluene diisocyanate (mixed isomer).  Specifically, isopropyl chloroformate is shipped approximately once per year, and the concentration of the isopropyl chloroformate is 80-100%. The isopropyl chloroformate is shipped cold at approximately 32 degrees Fahrenheit and is shipped in an "isotainer." The isotainer has a steel frame to protect the tank from external damage. The tank valves are located at the top of the tank and the material is discharged from these valves by pressurizing with nitrogen. All of the lines are pressure tested prior to direct discharge of the material into the incinerator. The likelihood of an entire tanker release is very remote. RIS has also developed special waste procedures that provide additional specific instructions, which must be followed when managing isopropyl chloroformate. The special waste procedures include information on the toxicity of the chemical as well as instructions for first aid and response in the event of a spill or release. 



Toluene diisocyanate (mixed isomer) ("TDI"), formaldehyde solutions and toluene-2,4-diisocyante ("TDI") are received in drums several times a year. A Worst-Case release would involve the contents of an entire 55-gallon drum of TDI or formaldehyde solution being released. It is unlikely that an entire 55- gallon drum of TDI of Formaldehyde solution would be released without mitigation. In the event that a drum of TDI or formaldehyde solution developed a leak, RIS would take steps to contain the leak and process the container immediately.



The assumptions used to determine the Worst-Case off-site release scenarios were highly conservative, and do not consider the preventative measures currently incorporated into RIS' standard operating procedures, or the e

mergency response procedures that would minimize or prevent potential off-site releases. For example, routine inspections of tanks, tankers and other containers help prevent the potential for a spill. In the event of an incident, materials would be secondarily contained. Secondary containment is designed to mitigate release. In addition, RIS' ERT members would immediately act to contain and clean up the waste material, and the release rate to the air would be minimal.



Five Year Accident History

RIS has not had an accidental release of a regulated chemical within the last five years at the RIS facility. Furthermore, RIS has not had an accidental release of a regulated chemical in the history of its facility. 



Emergency Response Program

RIS has plans and agreements in place with local response organizations to respond to emergencies at the RIS facility. RIS' Contingency Plan addresses various types of potential emergency situations, including spills, fires, civil unrest, associate injuries, earthquakes and high winds. Under its Contingency Plan, RIS will notify and work with the Lorain County Office of Emergency Management and Homeland Security ("LCOEMHS"), the local fire departments, sheriff, and hospital to control most emergency situations. A crisis communication plan is also in place to address more serious incidents with members of the local community. In extreme emergency situations, RIS may notify and seek assistance from the following organizations: 

?    Lorain County Red Cross,

?    Army Corps of Engineers,

?    CHEMTREC,

?    Environmental Emergency Response Center, U.S. EPA Region V,

?    Lorain County Office of Emergency Management and Homeland Security,

?    National Response Center, and 

?    Ohio EPA Emergency Response. 



Several of RIS' key Operations personnel are trained as Emergency Coordinators ("EC's") to manage emergency situations at the RIS facility. An EC is on-site or on-call 24 hours per day, seven days per week. It is the EC's responsibility t

o determine the degree of emergency and coordinate response actions accordingly. RIS employs an Emergency Response Team to act as first responders during most emergency situations. These qualified and trained RIS associates immediately clean up chemical spills and extinguish small fires. They are trained in first aid and CPR and provide limited medical assistance to injured associates. The EC may assemble the appropriate response team for any emergency situation by utilizing ERT members, operations personnel, safety and health professionals employed by RIS, and any appropriate off-site emergency management personnel. 



In Conclusion 

RIS has a continued commitment to maintain and improve safety at its facility. RIS' business success and its commitment to protection of human health and the environment are consistent and complementary goals. RIS is committed to maintaining an environmentally sound, safe, and healthy workplace for the benefit of our associates and our community. RIS is in compliance with State and Federal regulations regarding working conditions and accident prevention. RIS communicates its safety, health and environmental achievements and challenges openly, honestly, clearly, and professionally with associates, customers, our community, and government agencies.
